Altruistic Celebrity Chef Wants To Keep Wages Low

Jos√© Andr√©s has spent years crafting his public image as a charitable restaurateur, while quietly opposing efforts to raise worker pay.

children.text: By
John Besche
Click here to this article online
Between hobnobbing at the
TIME 100 Gala
clashing
with former President Donald Trump, promoting his book on MSNBC‚Äôs
Morning Joe
, starring in a
Ron Howard documentary
, dishing out
meals to refugees
at the Ukrainian border, and cinching a
nomination
for the Nobel Peace Prize, celebrity chef Jos√© Andr√©s has made a name for himself as a philanthropic restaurateur with an altruistic vision for his business empire.

Yet, back in his home base of Washington, D.C., Andr√©s‚Äô company is trying to block restaurant workers from receiving better pay. Campaign finance records show Andr√©s‚Äô firm is helping fund opposition to a ballot initiative that would phase out the lower minimum wage for the city‚Äôs tipped workers ‚Äî despite Andr√©s‚Äô calls to eliminate the subminimum tipped wage in New York. Andr√©s previously
opposed
a similar D.C. tipped wage initiative, which voters overwhelmingly passed in 2018 before the city council blocked it.

The episode highlights the contradiction between the saintly image Andr√©s has carefully cultivated, and his Washington-based restaurant empire‚Äôs focus on the bottom line: While Andr√©s generates headlines with displays of generosity, he‚Äôs working to deny a steady, living wage to his own employees and tens of thousands of other D.C. workers.

Andr√©s ‚Äî who owns 31 restaurants, including Michelin-starred minibar in Washington and Hudson Yards anchor Mercado Little Spain in New York ‚Äî is part of a group of restaurant owners who together have spent more than $350,000 opposing the D.C. initiative. While restaurant industry representatives say they are doing so to keep their operations afloat and staff employed, advocates for the ballot measure say restaurant owners are simply trying to crack down on worker organizing and demands for better working conditions inspired by the turmoil of the COVID-19 pandemic.

‚ÄúPeople love and respect this man so much for the humanitarian work he does, as they should,‚Äù said a server at a Jos√© Andr√©s restaurant in D.C., who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of retaliation. ‚ÄúThe idea that he is so in favor of helping refugees and immigrants, how can you be that pro-immigrant and be opposed to raising wages for the many, many immigrants that work for your company? It doesn‚Äôt add up.‚Äù
A Longtime Fight Against Better Worker Pay

The District of Columbia Tip Credit Elimination Act of 2021 ‚Äî Initiative 82 ‚Äî is on the ballot for D.C. voters in November. If passed, the measure would gradually increase tipped workers‚Äô base pay to meet the higher minimum wage for all workers by 2027. The tipped wage in Washington is currently $5.35 per hour, compared to $16.10 for other workers.
District
restaurateurs
including Andr√©s ‚Äî the bulk of whose business is in D.C. ‚Äî have put together hundreds of thousands of dollars to oppose the initiative. A recent campaign finance
report

revealed that Andr√©s‚Äô restaurant group ThinkFoodGroup LLC contributed $10,000 to the No to I-82 campaign on September 1. According to the report, No to I-82 had spent $80,952 in a two-month period over the second half of the summer, with $52,248 in cash on hand at the end of the period. The D.C. Committee to Build a Better Restaurant Industry (Yes on I-82)
spent
$3,039 and retained $5,487 at the end of the same period.

children.text: When asked to provide comment, Andr√©s public relations representative said in late September that he was not available because he had limited internet access during his humanitarian mission to Puerto Rico in the aftermath of Hurricane Fiona. Later that week, Andr√©s
delivered
a keynote address at the White House Conference on Hunger, Nutrition, and Health, making a point to thank his ‚Äúfellow food fighters.‚Äù Earlier this week, when
The Lever
again requested comment, his spokesperson said it was still unlikely, despite Andr√©s no longer being in Puerto Rico.

Initiative 82 comes four years after a previous incarnation of the ballot measure, Initiative 77, passed by a 10 percent margin but was overturned by the D.C. Council. Congress has 30 days to review all legislation passed in D.C. as a condition of the District‚Äôs home rule, a provision that allowed then-Rep. Mark Meadows (R-N.C.) to
introduce
an amendment to prevent its enactment. The council beat him to it, with eight of its 13 members
voting
to repeal the measure.
Chef Andr√©s opposed Initiative 77 in 2018, with his company
warning

voters that ending the subminimum wage for tipped workers would result in price hikes and thus lower tips, prompting job cuts. This slippery slope argument ‚Äî while commonly deployed by restaurant industry lobbyists and elite newspaper
opinion
sections
‚Äî has no basis in reality. Data
show
restaurant workers in states without a lower tipped wage generally make out as well or better than workers who receive a subminimum tipped wage.
In 2020, Andr√©s went on to sign a letter
urging

then-New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo to eliminate the tipped wage. Andr√©s was quoted saying, ‚ÄúLife is complicated and nuances are important. I‚Äôm supporting this because I have big restaurants in New York and a lot of restaurants in D.C. This new proposal in New York is a much more forward-thinking pragmatic response.‚Äù
The New York
letter

additionally called for greater tip sharing and payroll tax relief for restaurants emerging from the COVID-19 pandemic shutdown, arguing this would result in greater racial pay equity while jump-starting the industry‚Äôs recovery.
Leading The Charge For Worker Protection

Kathy Hollinger, president and chief executive of the Restaurant Association of Metropolitan Washington (RAMW), a regional trade group that lobbies on behalf of restaurant owners, said in a written statement to
The Lever
that the D.C. initiative is ‚Äúnot good for our market‚Ä¶ Restaurant operators and tipped employees are standing together to oppose this measure to save the vibrancy of our restaurant industry.‚Äù
Greg Casten ‚Äî an RAMW board member and proprietor of waterfront seafood strongholds Tony and Joe‚Äôs, Nick‚Äôs Riverside Grill, and The Point, as well as Ivy City Smokehouse ‚Äî told
The Lever
in an interview that after 45 years in the restaurant industry, he fears that the D.C. area has become unfriendly to businesses like his and worries for up-and-coming entrepreneurs.
According to Casten, the government, not business owners,
stands to profit
the most from Initiative 82, by increasing the amount of taxable payroll.
‚ÄúThe good waiters will go where they can make more money,‚Äù Casten said.

He fears that in the aftermath of Initiative 82 ‚Äî which he conceded will likely pass ‚Äî service standards will fall, chalking it up to the ‚Äúcasualization of the eating process, with robots delivering orders.‚Äù Right now, says Casten, ‚ÄúWhen [servers] look at the table and say ‚Äòboy that guy is paying my salary,‚Äô you‚Äôre going to be more attentive.‚Äù

Initiative 82 proposer and longtime D.C. server Ryan O‚ÄôLeary said that this dynamic is part of the problem in the first place, and it has created the conditions for tipped workers to feel unsafe and powerless in the workplace.‚ÄúAs a queer guy, I‚Äôve experienced harassment from both men and women customers, and I‚Äôve never felt comfortable pushing back or standing up for myself because I‚Äôm worried if they‚Äôre my only table, they might be my hourly wage for that hour,‚Äù O‚ÄôLeary told
The Lever
. ‚ÄúEven if it goes beyond words, to touching.‚Äù

children.caption: Ryan O‚ÄôLeary protesting for fair wages. (Photo Credit: Alexandra Charitan)

children.text: O‚ÄôLeary added: ‚ÄúIn states without a subminimum wage, the rate of harassment in the workplace is half,‚Äù citing a
study
commissioned by his former employer, One Fair Wage, an organization working to eliminate the subminimum wage nationally.

Such experiences inspired O‚ÄôLeary to start a Facebook group for tipped front-of-house workers at the Hamilton Hotel, a four-star hotel two blocks from the White House. O‚ÄôLeary said it was a space where workers could share memes, pick up shifts, and post grievances. It was also through this Facebook page that O‚ÄôLeary learned many of his colleagues didn‚Äôt realize they qualified for expanded pandemic unemployment benefits.

‚ÄúRestaurants were decimated during the pandemic.‚Äù Still, O‚ÄôLeary said, ‚Äú[Much of Initiative 82 activism] stems a lot from employees realizing their worth [during the shutdown]. When we had extended benefits, it gave us the means to pursue certifications and GEDs. That‚Äôs why so many places are unionizing now.‚Äù
The anonymous Jos√© Andr√©s server agreed that ‚Äúthe moment was ripe.‚Äù

‚ÄúWage increase will not just affect servers,‚Äù the server said. ‚ÄúIt will also affect bussers and food runners who most people think make $20/hr, but they get tipped out and they make a lot less money than we do. They deserve to make more. They deserve to have more security in what they‚Äôre expected to make‚Ä¶ The executives and the office staff at TFG make great salaries. If you can afford to pay your executives six figure salaries, can you not afford to pay your workers $15 an hour?‚Äù
Rep. Bobby Scott (D-Va.), who first proposed legislation in 2017 to increase the federal minimum wage to $15 and eliminate lower tipped wages for workers nationally, said in a statement to
The Lever
, ‚ÄúWe know that, when tipped workers are paid the full minimum wage, they have greater financial security and can provide for themselves and their families.‚Äù

He continued: ‚ÄúWhen workers earn decent wages, they strengthen their local economies. Simply put, by eliminating the subminimum wage for tipped workers, we can help ensure that hundreds of thousands of hardworking Americans can make ends meet and strengthen the economy.‚Äù
Progressives sought to include Scott‚Äôs Raise the Wage Act in President Joe Biden‚Äôs COVID-19 relief bill, but conservative Democratic senators quashed
the effort
. O‚ÄôLeary, a supporter of Scott and his Raise the Wage legislation, thinks that if Congress won‚Äôt intervene to ensure a living wage for tipped workers, it falls on workers at the local level.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been 31 years since the subminimum wage was raised nationally,‚Äù O‚ÄôLeary said. ‚ÄúIf they continue to not address the needs of workers, then workers will continue to address their needs at the local level.‚Äù

Some states have already eliminated the tipped minimum wage and continue to attract new business. California, for example, currently has a $15 minimum wage for workers at companies with more than 26 employees.
Andr√©s announced in January 2022 that his restaurant company would be opening three new restaurants in Los Angeles.
